facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 202 of 1953 filed as appeal under article 132(1) of the Constitution of India.

facts.text: Notification No. 4594 L. S. G. dated 25th April 1931 cancelled previous notifications and extended sections of 1922 Act to Patna Administration.

anchor.surface_text: In 1922 the Provincial Legislature enacted the Bihar and Orissa Municipal Act, 1922  Bihar and Orissa Act VII of 1922 .

anchor.surface_text: It was made under section 3 1 f , therefore, it will be necessary to examine  1  whether the notification travels beyond the impugned portion of the Act and  2  if not, whether section 3 1  f  is itself ultra vires. But we cannot do this until we examine the decision

issues.text: Whether section 3(1)(f) is itself ultra vires

anchor.surface_text: It was made under section 3 1 f , therefore, it will be necessary to examine  1  whether the notification travels beyond the impugned portion of the Act and  2  if not, whether section 3 1  f  is itself ultra vires. But we cannot do this until we examine the decision

issues.text: Whether section 5 of the Patna Administration Act of 1915 is ultra vires

anchor.surface_text: It is not necessary to examine the vires of section 5 of the Act of 1915 which was also impugned because no action taken under it has hurt the appellant and so he cannot question its vires. The result is that the appeal succeeds.

arguments.claim: Petitioner cannot challenge notification of 25th April 1931 as it does not affect him

anchor.surface_text: The first question is whether the notification of 26th April, 1931, can be attacked by the petitioner. In our Opinion, it cannot. As we have already pointed out, this notification gave a sort of fresh Municipal Code to the Patna Administration area.

arguments.claim: Notification of 23rd April 1951 ultra vires as it changes policy by omitting sections 4,5,6 requiring hearing of objections

arguments.claim: Section 3(1)(f) intra vires provided no essential change or policy alteration in restrictions/modifications

holdings.text: The notification of 25th/26th April 1931 cannot be attacked by the petitioner as it does not affect him.

anchor.surface_text: The first question is whether the notification of 26th April, 1931, can be attacked by the petitioner. In our Opinion, it cannot. As we have already pointed out, this notification gave a sort of fresh Municipal Code to the Patna Administration area. But it did number affect

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petitioner lacks standing as notification applied only to Patna Administration area, not Patna Village where appellant resides.

holdings.text: The notification dated 23rd April 1951 is ultra vires as it effects a radical change in the policy of the Bihar and Orissa Municipal Act 1922 by omitting sections 4, 5 and 6.

anchor.surface_text: The numberification of 23rd April, 1951 does, in our opinion, effect a radical change in the policy of the Act.  I  5 I.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Omitting ss.4-6 removes statutory guarantee of hearing objections before imposing taxation, altering legislative policy; violates limits on delegation per Delhi Laws Act.

holdings.text: Section 3(1)(f) of the Patna Administration Act 1915 is intra vires provided restrictions and modifications do not effect essential change or alter policy.

anchor.surface_text: Subject to that limitation we hold that section 3 1  f  is intra vires, that is to say, we hold that any section or sect

holdings.reasoning_summary: Permits selecting/applying sections of 1922 Act as in Burah and Delhi Laws Act majority; modifications limited to minor/local adjustments, not policy change or essential features.

holdings.text: Vires of section 5 not examined as no action under it affected the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: It is not necessary to examine the vires of section 5 of the Act of 1915 which was also impugned because no action taken under it has hurt the appellant and so he cannot question its vires. The result is that the appeal succeeds.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lack of injury to appellant deprives standing to challenge.

holdings.text: Appeal succeeds; section 3(1)(f) intra vires (with limits), 23rd April 1951 notification ultra vires.

precedents.citation: In re The Delhi Laws Act, 1912 1

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, purporting to apply In re The Delhi Laws Act, 1912 1  held that the impugned sections and the numberifications companyplained of are intra vires. We are only companycerned with the Patna Village area in this case. The appellant and those he represents all live in that area and are the ones who impugn the validity of the taxes levied on them.

precedents.case_name: In re The Delhi Laws Act, 1912
precedents.cited_proposition: impugned sections and notifications are intra vires

anchor.surface_text: the decision of this Court, in the Delhi Laws Act case 1 .  1  1951 S.C.R. 747, Because of the elaborate care with which every aspect of the problem was examined in that case, the decision has tended to become diffuse, but if one companycentrates on the matters actually decided and forgets for a moment the reasons given, a plain pattern emerges leaving only a narrow margin of doubt for ,future dispute.

precedents.case_name: In re The Delhi Laws Act, 1912
precedents.cited_proposition: limits on delegation of legislative power to executive including extension, modification, selection of laws
precedents.cited_holding: executive authority can be authorised to modify laws but not in essential features or policy; upheld extension of whole or part of enactments with minor modifications

anchor.surface_text: Mukherjea and Bose JJ., who swung the balance, held that number only companyld an entire enactment with 1951 S.C.R. 747- modification be extended but also a part of one and indeed that was the actual decision in Burahs case 1  on which the majority founded  see Mukherjea J. at page 1000 and Bose J. at pages 1106 and 1121 .

precedents.case_name: In re The Delhi Laws Act, 1912
precedents.cited_proposition: provision allowing Provincial Government to extend enactments with restrictions and modifications is valid
precedents.cited_holding: modification confined to minor changes not affecting policy

anchor.surface_text: that was the actual decision in Burahs case 1  on which the majority founded  see Mukherjea J. at page 1000 and Bose J. at pages 1106 and 1121 . But Mukherjea and Bose JJ., both placed a very restricted meaning on the words restriction and modification and, as they swung the balance, their opinions must be accepted as the decision of the Court because their opinions embody the greatest companymon measure of agreement among the seven Judges.

anchor.surface_text: it follows that a section or sections can be picked out and applied, as in Burahs case 1  where just that was done also, for the same reason that the whole or a part of an Act can be modified it follows that a section can also be modified.

anchor.surface_text: the actual decision in Burahs case 1  on which the majority founded  see Mukherjea J. at page 1000 and Bose J. at pages 1106 and 1121 . But Mukherjea and Bose JJ., both placed a very restricted meaning on the words restriction and modification and, as they swung the balance, their opinions must be accepted as the decision of the Court because their opinions embody the greatest companymon measure of agreement among the seven Judges. anchor.surface_text: The result is that the appeal succeeds. We hold-  1  that section 3 1  f  is intra vire8 provided always that the words restriction and modification are used in the restricted sense set out above and  2  that the numberification of 23rd April, 1951, is ultra vires.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal succeeds; section 3(1)(f) held intra vires with limitation on modifications to not change policy or essential features; notification dated 23rd April, 1951 held ultra vires; no decision on section 5 or notification of 25th April, 1931.
